questions.text: Koenen's tumors are characteristically associated with which condition? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tuberous Sclerosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Koenen's tumors, or periungual fibromas, are benign skin growths commonly found around the nails. These tumors are a distinctive feature of tuberous sclerosis, a genetic disorder that causes non-cancerous tumors to form in many different organs, primarily the brain, eyes, heart, kidney, skin, and lungs. The presence of these tumors is one of the major clinical criteria used to diagnose tuberous sclerosis. They typically develop during puberty or later.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Neurofibromatosis: Incorrect. While neurofibromatosis can produce skin tumors, these are usually neurofibromas, which are different from the fibromas seen in tuberous sclerosis.
  • • Option A. Neurofibromatosis:
  • • Option C. Sturge-Weber syndrome: Incorrect. Sturge-Weber syndrome is associated with port-wine stains and neurological abnormalities, not Koenen's tumors.
  • • Option C. Sturge-Weber syndrome:
  • • Option D. Tuberculosis: Incorrect. Tuberculosis is an infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, primarily affecting the lungs, and does not cause Koenen's tumors.
  • • Option D. Tuberculosis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Koenen's tumors are associated with tuberous sclerosis and are indicative of the disease's complex multisystem involvement. The appearance of these tumors can help in the clinical diagnosis of tuberous sclerosis, particularly in patients with other neurocutaneous features.

questions.text: Which medication does Gitelman’s syndrome pharmacologically resemble? NEET 2016:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Thiazide

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Gitelman’s syndrome is closely related to the effects of thiazide diuretics due to a mutation in the Na-Cl co-transporter in the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) of the kidney. This mutation results in symptoms similar to those produced by thiazide diuretics, such as hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis and salt-wasting. The syndrome typically presents a milder clinical course compared to other conditions such as Bartter’s syndrome, with additional features like hypocalciuria and severe hypomagnesemia.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Furosemide: Incorrect as furosemide acts on the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, not the DCT.
  • • Option
  • • B. Furosemide:
  • • Option C. Spironolactone: Incorrect because it is a potassium-sparing diuretic, opposite in effect to the salt-wasting seen in Gitelman’s.
  • • Option
  • • C. Spironolactone:
  • • Option D. Amiloride: Incorrect as amiloride also conserves potassium, which does not align with the hypokalemia observed in Gitelman’s syndrome.
  • • Option
  • • D. Amiloride:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gitelman’s syndrome mirrors the effects of thiazide diuretics due to its impact on the Na-Cl co-transporter in the distal convoluted tubule.

questions.text: The most common cause of Central Pontine Myelinolysis (CPM) is the rapid correction of? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Hyponatremia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Central pontine myelinolysis (CPM), also known as osmotic demyelination syndrome, is an acute demyelinating condition primarily affecting the central pons. It occurs when chronic hyponatremia (low sodium levels) is corrected too rapidly. This rapid correction leads to a shift in osmolality, resulting in damage to the myelin sheaths of nerve cells. CPM is commonly observed in chronic alcoholics or malnourished patients with chronic hyponatremia. Symptoms of CPM include dysphagia, dysarthria, pseudobulbar palsy, seizures, quadriparesis, and locked-in syndrome. The risk of CPM is significantly reduced if sodium levels are corrected slowly and carefully.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Hypokalemia : Rapid correction of low potassium levels is not associated with CPM.
  • • Option A. Hypokalemia
  • • Option B. Hypomagnesemia : Rapid correction of low magnesium levels does not cause CPM.
  • • Option B. Hypomagnesemia
  • • Option D. Hypocalcemia : Rapid correction of low calcium levels is not linked to CPM.
  • • Option D. Hypocalcemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Central pontine myelinolysis is most commonly caused by the rapid correction of chronic hyponatremia.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presented with infertility, and he has chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus. What is the likely disorder?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Kartagener's syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Kartagener's syndrome, a subset of primary ciliary dyskinesia, is characterized by the triad of chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus.
  • • Infertility in males is also a common feature due to the dysfunction of cilia and flagella, leading to impaired sperm motility.
  • • Situs inversus is a condition where the major visceral organs are mirrored from their normal positions, often seen in Kartagener's syndrome.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Cystic fibrosis : While patients with cystic fibrosis may also present with sinusitis, infertility, and bronchiectasis, they do not typically have situs inversus, which is specific to Kartagener's syndrome.
  • • Option B. Cystic fibrosis
  • • Option C. Mucoviscidosis : This is another term for cystic fibrosis, and thus the same reasoning applies as above.
  • • Option C. Mucoviscidosis
  • • Option D. Klinefelter syndrome : This genetic disorder can present with infertility but does not include chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, or situs inversus.
  • • Option D. Klinefelter syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kartagener's syndrome is characterized by the triad of chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus, and is associated with infertility in males due to primary ciliary dyskinesia.

questions.text: Patient after road traffic accident was brought to the emergency. His pulse rate was 130 beats per minute, blood pressure was 80/60 mm of Hg. He had multiple linear wheals over the body, and complained of difficulty in breathing. He mentioned hitting a beehive during the accident. On evaluation his ECG was normal, eFAST was negative, and chest X-ray was normal. This status of the patient could be best classified under which type of shock? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Anaphylactic shock

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Anaphylactic shock is a type of distributive shock resulting from a severe allergic reaction, in this case to bee stings. The clinical presentation includes:
  • • Tachycardia (130 bpm) Hypotension (80/60 mmHg) Urticaria (linear wheals) Respiratory symptoms (difficulty breathing) Clear history of allergen exposure (beehive)
  • • Tachycardia (130 bpm)
  • • Hypotension (80/60 mmHg)
  • • Urticaria (linear wheals)
  • • Respiratory symptoms (difficulty breathing)
  • • Clear history of allergen exposure (beehive)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Hemorrhagic shock : Though tachycardia and hypotension are present, the normal eFAST and absence of obvious bleeding sources make this unlikely. The presence of urticaria and respiratory symptoms point towards a different etiology.
  • • Option A. Hemorrhagic shock
  • • Option B. Cardiogenic shock : Normal ECG findings make this unlikely. Additionally, the presence of systemic symptoms like urticaria suggests a different pathophysiology.
  • • Option B. Cardiogenic shock
  • • Option C. Neurogenic shock : Typically presents with bradycardia due to unopposed vagal tone, not tachycardia as seen in this case. Also, neurogenic shock doesn't cause urticaria or respiratory symptoms.
  • • Option C. Neurogenic shock

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anaphylactic shock should be suspected when patients present with:
  • ➤ Sudden onset of systemic symptoms Clear exposure to a potential allergen Classic triad of hypotension, urticaria, and respiratory symptoms Tachycardia as a compensatory mechanism
  • ➤ Sudden onset of systemic symptoms
  • ➤ Clear exposure to a potential allergen
  • ➤ Classic triad of hypotension, urticaria, and respiratory symptoms
  • ➤ Tachycardia as a compensatory mechanism

questions.text: A 60-year-old with a history of COPD is brought to the ER with worsening dyspnea. ABG was done and pH was 7.3, pCO2 was 60 mmHg with HCO3- being 28 mEq/L. Which of the following is seen in this patient? ( INICET Nov 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Respiratory acidosis, hyperventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation

options.label: B
options.text: Respiratory alkalosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation

options.label: C
options.text: Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation

options.label: D
options.text: Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, adequate metabolic compensation

questions.correct_answer: C. Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) shows a pH of 7.3, indicating acidosis (normal pH: 7.35-7.45). The elevated pCO2 of 60 mmHg (normal: 35-45 mmHg) points to a respiratory cause of the acidosis, specifically respiratory acidosis. In COPD patients, chronic CO2 retention is common, leading to increased bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels as a compensatory mechanism. However, in acute respiratory acidosis, the metabolic compensation is typically inadequate, as seen by the HCO3- level of 28 mEq/L (normal: 22-28 mEq/L). The inadequate compensation suggests an acute exacerbation rather than a chronic condition, as chronic respiratory acidosis would have a more elevated bicarbonate level (>30 mEq/L).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Respiratory acidosis, hyperventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation: Hyperventilation leads to respiratory alkalosis, not acidosis. The patient's presentation does not fit this scenario.
  • • Option A. Respiratory acidosis, hyperventilation, inadequate
  • • metabolic compensation:
  • • Option B. Respiratory alkalosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation: Hypoventilation causes respiratory acidosis, not alkalosis. This choice is incorrect.
  • • Option B. Respiratory alkalosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation:
  • • Option D. Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, adequate metabolic compensation: Adequate metabolic compensation would show higher bicarbonate levels (>30 mEq/L). The patient's bicarbonate level indicates inadequate compensation, ruling out this option.
  • • Option D. Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, adequate metabolic compensation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In acute respiratory acidosis due to COPD exacerbation, expect hypoventilation and inadequate metabolic compensation, indicated by elevated pCO2 and only slightly elevated HCO3- levels.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The CT scan shows a hyperdense biconvex/lentiform collection adjacent to the inner table of the skull. This finding is characteristic of an extradural hematoma (EDH). The key features visible in this image are:
  • • Lens/biconvex shaped hemorrhage Does not cross suture lines Well-defined margins Usually associated with skull fracture and middle meningeal artery injury
  • • Lens/biconvex shaped hemorrhage
  • • Does not cross suture lines
  • • Well-defined margins
  • • Usually associated with skull fracture and middle meningeal artery injury
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Subdural hematoma : Appears as a crescent-shaped hemorrhage that can cross suture lines, which is not seen in this image.
  • • Option B. Subdural hematoma
  • • Option C. Subarachnoid hemorrhage : Appears as hyperdense blood following the brain sulci and cisterns, often described as a "starry night" appearance.
  • • Option C. Subarachnoid hemorrhage
  • • Option D. Intraparenchymal hemorrhage : Appears as a well-circumscribed hyperdense lesion within the brain tissue itself, often with surrounding edema.
  • • Option D. Intraparenchymal hemorrhage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Recognize the classic biconvex/lenticular shape of an extradural hematoma on CT Understand that EDH doesn't cross suture lines due to dural attachments Identify key differentiating features between various types of intracranial hemorrhages Appreciate the emergency nature of EDH as a neurosurgical emergency

questions.text: A young female presented with wheezing and shortness of breath with use of accessory muscles. She complains of similar episodes in the past in early mornings. Spirometry findings are as follows: FEV1/FVC ratio < 0.7 and FEV1 < 80% of the predicted value in a female patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Asthma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Asthma is characterized by episodes of wheezing, shortness of breath, and use of accessory muscles, which often worsen in the early mornings or at night. Spirometry findings typically show an obstructive pattern, with a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio (< 0.7) and an FEV1 < 80% of the predicted value. This pattern is indicative of obstructive lung disease, which is consistent with asthma.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Interstitial Lung Disease (ILD) : ILD typically presents as a restrictive lung disease, not obstructive. It shows a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio and reduced lung volumes.
  • • Option B. Interstitial Lung Disease (ILD)
  • • Option C. Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF) : IPF is a type of ILD and also presents with a restrictive pattern, not obstructive. It involves progressive fibrosis of the lung tissue.
  • • Option C. Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF)
  • • Option D. Silicosis : Silicosis is another form of restrictive lung disease caused by inhalation of silica dust, leading to fibrosis and restrictive spirometry patterns.
  • • Option D. Silicosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Asthma is an obstructive lung disease characterized by episodes of wheezing and shortness of breath, especially in the early mornings, with spirometry showing a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio and FEV1.

questions.text: A patient having hypertension, is on thiazides and is complaining of fatigue and hypokalemia. Which of the following drug can prevent potassium loss?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Amiloride

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Thiazide diuretics, such as hydrochlorothiazide, indapamide, chlorthalidone, and metolazone, are known for causing potassium wasting, which can result in hypokalemia and associated symptoms like fatigue. To counteract this effect, potassium-sparing diuretics can be used.
  • • Amiloride is an epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) inhibitor, which is a type of potassium-sparing diuretic. It helps prevent potassium loss by inhibiting sodium reabsorption in the distal tubules of the kidneys, thereby reducing potassium excretion.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Furosemide : This is a loop diuretic, which also causes potassium wasting and is not suitable for preventing potassium loss.
  • • Option A. Furosemide
  • • Option C. Acetazolamide : This is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor diuretic, which is not typically used for potassium conservation and can also cause electrolyte imbalances.
  • • Option C. Acetazolamide
  • • Option D. Indapamide : This is another thiazide-like diuretic, which also causes potassium wasting and does not prevent potassium loss.
  • • Option D. Indapamide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic that can be used to prevent potassium loss in patients on thiazide diuretics.
